infoSections.text: **Bandpass filtering** allows frequencies within a specific range to pass while attenuating frequencies outside that range. It is used to isolate signals of interest, such as detecting brain wave activity in EEG signals.

**Notch filtering** (or **band-stop filtering**) removes a specific frequency range while allowing others to pass. It is useful for eliminating unwanted noise, such as removing 60 Hz power line interference from biosignals.
Although most implementations abstract away the difference between FIR and IIR filters, it may be useful to have a general understanding of their differences.

**Finite impulse response (FIR) filters** only rely on previous inputs to calculate the current filtered output. They have the important property of linear phase, meaning that all frequencies present in the signal have the same delay before being reflected in the output signal. This maintains the timing of frequencies more accurately, but it comes at the cost of requiring a higher filter order for the same specifications (i.e., more past samples are included for the same attenuation).

**Infinite impulse response (IIR) filters** do not have linear phase, but they can be designed to have approximately linear phase in the passband of the filter. They donâ€™t require nearly the same order as FIR filters, letting them use fewer multiply and add instructions to execute in code. This makes them an excellent choice for real-time systems.
